entries.title: Turkish drone maker Baykar to invest $300 mln to develop jet engine, CEO says
entries.snippet: Baykar, a leading Turkish drone manufacturer, is set to invest $300 million to develop its own jet engines, addressing supply chain challenges by bringing more component production in-house. Known for its prominent TB2 and Akinci drones, which have seen action in Ukraine, Azerbaijan, and North Africa, Baykar's CEO Haluk Bayraktar highlighted the importance of engine production to the company's strategy. They will develop a turboprop engine for Akinci and a turbofan engine for the Kizilelma unmanned combat drone, which currently use Ukrainian engines. Baykar is collaborating with Ukraine’s Ivchenko-Progress on a separate turbofan engine project. The company envisions drones replacing piloted fighter jets within four decades and is preparing for this shift by focusing on autonomous aircraft development. Baykar's new Ukrainian factory is 80% complete and expected to be operational by August 2025. The company's revenues reached $2 billion last year, with exports representing 90% of its sales, constituting about a third of Turkey's defense and aerospace exports.

entries.title: Poland prepares for talks on buying over 100 HIMARS rocket launchers
entries.snippet: Poland is gearing up for negotiations to secure over 100 HIMARS rocket launchers from U.S. defense contractor Lockheed Martin, as part of a framework agreement for 486 units. General Artur Kuptel from the Armaments Agency indicated that these talks would commence soon, despite allegations of procurement delays by the current ruling coalition, which assumed power in December 2023. Poland plans significant defense spending, allocating 4.1% of GDP to defense in 2024, the highest among NATO countries, with an increase to 4.7% promised in 2025. Poland has been arranging other defense procurements, including a precision rocket system from South Korea and an order for 72 K239 Chunmoo rocket launchers, with deliveries starting in 2026. Local production of ammunition for these systems is also planned.

entries.title: Japan accelerates missile deployment amid rising regional tensions
entries.snippet:
Japan is expediting its deployment of domestically developed long-range missiles amid rising tensions in the region. The Defense Ministry announced plans to roll out the Type-12 anti-ship missiles with a 1,000 km range at Camp Kengun in Kumamoto by March 2026—one year ahead of schedule. This acceleration aligns with Japan’s strategic move to bolster its strike-back capabilities, especially in response to China’s assertive naval actions, North Korea’s threats, and concerns about Russia.

Breaking from its post-WWII pacifist stance, Japan had already shifted defense policies in 2022, adopting a five-year strategy identifying China as a primary threat and strengthening ties with the U.S. As part of this military buildup, Japan aims to increase defense spending to 2% of GDP by 2027. The Defense Ministry has requested a record ¥8.8 trillion ($59.9 billion) budget for fiscal 2026, prioritizing long-range missiles and drones. Alongside the Type-12 missiles, Japan will also deploy U.S.-made Tomahawk missiles and seek to enhance coastal defense with unmanned aerial, surface, and underwater drones to address military understaffing due to its aging population.

entries.title: AI lab Lila Sciences tops $1.3 billion valuation with new Nvidia backing
entries.snippet:
AI startup Lila Sciences has raised $115 million in an extension of its Series A funding round, pushing its total valuation to over $1.3 billion. The round included investment from Nvidia’s venture arm, among others, bringing Lila’s total Series A funding to $350 million and total capital raised to $550 million. Founded in 2023 by Flagship Pioneering, Lila aims to revolutionize scientific discovery through “scientific superintelligence,” combining specialized AI models with automated laboratories.

The new funding will support the development of Lila’s “AI Science Factories”—robotic labs guided by AI to conduct continuous experiments—and facilitate the company’s expansion into a newly leased 235,500-square-foot space in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Lila plans to commercialize its platform by offering enterprise software access to companies in fields like energy, semiconductors, and drug development.

Unlike labs focused mainly on internet-trained large language models, Lila emphasizes generating proprietary scientific data through original experiments, aiming to accelerate breakthroughs. CEO Geoffrey von Maltzahn stated the platform has already enabled thousands of discoveries and envisions a new form of the scientific method. The push aligns with a broader trend of venture capital's growing interest in AI for scientific applications.

entries.title: Samsung expects best profit since 2022, as AI boom squeezes commodity chip supply
entries.snippet:
Samsung Electronics announced expectations for its highest quarterly profit in over three years, forecasting an operating profit of 12.1 trillion won ($8.5 billion) for Q3 2025—a 32% year-on-year increase and significantly above market expectations. The surge is primarily driven by strong demand and rising prices for conventional DRAM and NAND memory chips, fueled by a global push for AI servers and data center infrastructure. Although Samsung has lagged in advanced AI chip production compared to competitors like SK Hynix and has faced slow progress in supplying HBM chips to Nvidia, commodity memory chip sales have cushioned the impact.

The company also expects record quarterly revenue of 86 trillion won, aided by a weaker Korean won. Despite these gains, challenges such as potential U.S.-China trade conflicts and rare earth material export controls persist. Samsung plans to roll out performance-based stock compensation for all South Korean employees. Meanwhile, analysts anticipate continued demand and limited supply for commodity memory into 2026, and expect Samsung’s next-gen HBM4 technology to support further growth and competitiveness in AI chip markets.

entries.title: OpenAI is on pace to dominate a $700 billion market by 2030
entries.snippet: OpenAI is on course to dominate a rapidly expanding artificial intelligence market projected to reach $700 billion by 2030. Its early-mover advantage, according to JPMorgan analysts, positions it as the frontrunner in the AI arms race, even as it faces competition from more cost-effective models such as China’s DeepSeek. If OpenAI achieves a forecasted revenue of $174 billion by decade’s end, it would command approximately 25% of the total market. The company has already shown substantial dominance, with ChatGPT boasting 800 million weekly users—over 10% of the global adult population. OpenAI’s dissemination of AI tools, including its swift adoption of the Sora AI video app (1 million downloads in five days), exemplifies the unprecedented speed and scale of its user engagement. Researchers note that the rise of ChatGPT lacks modern parallels and places OpenAI far ahead of rivals like Meta AI and xAI’s Grok.

entries.title: Global fertility rates to decline, shifting population burden to low-income countries
entries.snippet: By the end of the century, global fertility rates are expected to drop below levels necessary for population maintenance in almost all countries, leading to a divide where live births predominantly occur in low-income nations. This is projected to result in economic and political challenges for these countries, particularly those in sub-Saharan Africa, which will see a significant portion of global births. A study in The Lancet projects that by 2050, 76% of countries will fall below the replacement fertility level, increasing to 97% by 2100. The global fertility rate has already decreased from 5 births per woman in 1950 to 2.2 in 2021. Nations with extremely low fertility rates, like South Korea and Serbia, face potential workforce shortages. The study emphasizes the need for improved access to contraception and female education, suggesting that future economic growth will depend on open immigration policies to counter shrinking populations. The findings are grounded in data spanning from 1950 to 2021, noting potential limitations due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

entries.title: Heat exposure of older people across world to double by 2050, finds study
entries.snippet: By 2050, heat exposure for older people will at least double globally, exacerbated by both climate change and an aging population, according to a study in Nature Communications. An estimated additional 250 million elderly individuals will face dangerous heat levels of 37.5°C. This will disproportionately impact the global south, which is hotter and poorer, intensifying health and social vulnerabilities. The elderly are particularly susceptible to heat due to decreased thermoregulation, chronic illnesses, and dependence on medications that cause dehydration. Regions like Asia, Africa, South America, and Europe will see significant increases in heat exposure for older adults. The study emphasizes the need for better infrastructure, public health adaptations, and intergenerational equity to address these challenges, highlighting the divide between the preparedness of the richer north and the more vulnerable south. It calls for proactive measures to protect the elderly from the imminent risk of heat-related illnesses and deaths.

entries.title: More countries, including China, are grappling with shrinking and aging populations
entries.snippet: Countries like China, Japan, Italy, and South Korea are facing significant challenges due to declining and aging populations. China’s population decreased for the third consecutive year in 2024, dropping to 1.408 billion. Japan's population has been shrinking since 2008, with forecasts predicting it to decrease further. Similarly, Italy is experiencing a record low in birth rates, and South Korea nominally reversed population decline due to an influx of foreigners, despite a continuing drop in birth rates. These demographic changes are causing concerns about economic growth and the ability to support increasing elderly populations. Governments in these countries are introducing measures such as raising the retirement age, encouraging higher birth rates through financial incentives, and adapting policies to address social and cultural factors contributing to the decline. The United Nations projects that the global population will peak around 10.3 billion in 60 years before starting to decline.

entries.title: $600 trillion of wealth rests on productivity or inflation burst
entries.snippet: A Reuters column highlights that global net worth has surged to $600 trillion, nearly quadrupling since 2000, vastly outpacing global GDP growth. This wealth, now over 5.4 times world GDP, is increasingly disconnected from real economic fundamentals, with much of the growth stemming from paper gains and cumulative inflation. Only 30% of the increase has come from real investment, while rising asset values have also fueled a surge in global debt to 2.6 times GDP. McKinsey warns this imbalance makes the global economy vulnerable, with future financial stability hinging on whether productivity—potentially through AI innovations—can close the gap, or if prolonged inflation will erode wealth. Investors are hedging bets across booming tech stocks and gold, as market volatility reflects divergent future scenarios. For U.S. savers, the outcome could mean a wealth swing of up to $160,000 by 2033 depending on whether growth or inflation dominates.

entries.title: Over 40% of agentic AI projects will be scrapped by 2027, Gartner says
entries.snippet: According to a report by Gartner, over 40% of agentic artificial intelligence (AI) projects are expected to be scrapped by the end of 2027 due to rising costs and unclear business value. Despite significant investments from major tech firms like Salesforce and Oracle in AI systems that can autonomously carry out tasks, many of these projects remain in early, experimental stages and are often driven by hype rather than practical application. Gartner notes a trend of “agent washing,” where vendors mislabel conventional AI tools as agentic without true autonomous capabilities. Currently, only about 130 vendors genuinely offer agentic AI among thousands claiming to do so. Gartner's Anushree Verma highlights that most current agentic AI lacks the maturity to deliver real returns on investment and cannot yet handle complex or nuanced instructions. However, the firm predicts improvements, projecting that by 2028, 15% of day-to-day business decisions will be autonomously made using agentic AI, and 33% of enterprise software applications will incorporate such technology, up significantly from 2024 levels.

entries.title: Seeing double - increasing trust in agentic AI
entries.snippet:
The article explores the emerging trend of agentic AI—an advanced form of artificial intelligence that utilizes autonomous agents capable of decision-making, learning, and communication to optimize business operations. Gartner predicts that by 2028, one-third of enterprise software will include agentic AI, but over 40% of such projects may be canceled by 2027 due to complexity, high costs, and implementation challenges. For agentic AI to succeed at scale, organizations must emphasize real-time, trustworthy data, robust governance, and seamless integration between systems to reduce risks like hallucinations from large language models (LLMs). The deployment of multiple communicating agents requires reliable data infrastructure, persistent memory, and scalability.

Technologies such as data fabric—offering a unified, context-rich data layer—are highlighted as crucial, in contrast to more decentralized data mesh models. Standards like Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Agent-to-Agent (A2A) communication are paving the way for enhanced agent interaction. Guardrails ensuring ethical and secure implementations are essential. Ultimately, the article underscores the need for centralized, clean, and accessible data systems to fully unlock the value of agentic AI in enterprise environments.

entries.title: US senator seeks Commerce Department investigation into Megaspeed
entries.snippet: U.S. Senator Tom Cotton has requested the Commerce Department to investigate Singapore-based cloud computing firm Megaspeed for allegedly diverting Nvidia AI chips in violation of U.S. export controls. His letter, prompted by an October report in The New York Times, claims Megaspeed funneled chips intended for AI use to Malaysia and Indonesia, later serving Chinese customers remotely. The Singapore Police confirmed ongoing investigations into the company for suspected legal breaches. Citing past Reuters reports on increasing demand for banned Nvidia products and China's alleged acquisition of these chips despite a ban, Cotton emphasized the national security threat posed by such diversions. He supports tighter enforcement measures, including chip location verification post-sale. This move coincides with President Trump’s recent imposition of 100% tariffs on Chinese exports and stricter export controls on critical software, reinforcing efforts to prevent U.S. technology access by adversarial nations.

entries.title: China launches customs crackdown on Nvidia AI chips
entries.snippet:
China has intensified its enforcement of chip import controls, focusing on curbing reliance on U.S.-made semiconductors, especially Nvidia's AI processors like the H20 and RTX Pro 6000D, which comply with U.S. export restrictions. In recent weeks, customs teams have been deployed to inspect semiconductor shipments at major ports, targeting not just Nvidia chips but also potential smuggling of other high-end processors. This move follows guidance from Chinese regulators urging tech companies like ByteDance and Alibaba to halt orders and testing of Nvidia products.

These checks are part of a broader campaign to reduce technology dependence on the U.S. and bolster domestic semiconductor development. Investigations have extended to potential false import declarations, with U.S. firm Tower Research under scrutiny for alleged hardware smuggling. The crackdown aligns with China's strategy to enhance local chip manufacturing capacity and performance, aiming to triple production next year. While Nvidia has stopped counting on China for future revenues, it previously made $4.6 billion in Q1 from Chinese sales before the U.S. temporarily restricted exports. Both Chinese customs and Nvidia declined to comment on the developments.

Initially aimed at stopping local companies from importing Nvidia’s chips designed under US export restrictions, the checks have now broadened to encompass all advanced semiconductors. This move is part of a broader strategy by Beijing to reduce reliance on American technology, combat potential smuggling of restricted high-end chips, and support the development of China's domestic chip industry in the global AI race. Additionally, Chinese authorities have instructed customs officials to scrutinize past import declarations for compliance.

entries.title: Hijacked satellites and orbiting space weapons: In the 21st century, space is the new battlefield
entries.snippet:
In the 21st century, space has emerged as a critical battlefield alongside land, sea, air, and cyberspace. The article, dated August 18, 2025, details the growing threat posed by space-based cyber and physical attacks. For example, pro-Russian hackers hijacked a satellite broadcasting in Ukraine, replacing programming with Russian military parade footage. Such actions demonstrate how easily satellites, which support GPS, military operations, and communications, can be compromised.

Over 12,000 satellites orbit Earth, making them vulnerable to cyber intrusions, particularly via outdated software. The 2022 hack on the Viasat network during the Russian invasion of Ukraine exemplifies this risk. U.S. officials also warn of a developing Russian nuclear anti-satellite weapon intended to cripple all satellites in low-Earth orbit, evoking Cold War-era fears akin to a new “Cuban Missile Crisis.”

Additionally, competition for lunar resources, particularly by the U.S., Russia, and China, is heating up. Nations plan nuclear-powered lunar bases to exploit materials like helium-3 for future energy production. The U.S. is advancing its security efforts through the Space Force and unmanned missions like the X-37B.

Tensions and strategic investments reflect a new era where control of space could determine future geopolitical and economic dominance.

entries.title: US Space Force warns of 'mind-boggling' build-up of Chinese capabilities
entries.snippet: General Chance Saltzman, chief of the US Space Force, has expressed significant concerns over China's rapid expansion of military capabilities in space, warning of the increased risk of orbital warfare. He emphasized that the number and speed of development of Chinese space weapons are alarming. During his European tour, Saltzman highlighted the necessity of cooperation between the US and European allies to bolster deterrence capabilities. The US Space Force, established in 2019 by then-president Donald Trump, monitors over 46,000 objects in orbit and has about 10,000 personnel. China and Russia have developed advanced satellite technologies, raising security concerns. Despite Beijing's dismissal of US claims, President Xi Jinping has restructured space, cyber, and information operations within the Chinese military. The US remains reliant on private sector partnerships, including with Elon Musk's SpaceX, to advance its space defenses amidst ongoing global competition.

entries.title: Trump to move U.S. Space Command headquarters from Colorado to Alabama
entries.snippet:
President Donald Trump announced the relocation of the U.S. Space Command headquarters from Colorado to Huntsville, Alabama, citing national security benefits and the Air Force’s original 2021 preference. This decision follows a prolonged bipartisan dispute involving three administrations and reflects intense lobbying from both Colorado and Alabama. Trump made the announcement alongside Alabama lawmakers, including Rep. Mike Rogers and Sen. Katie Britt, who touted the economic benefits, including 1,600 new jobs. Trump implied Colorado’s mail-in voting practices influenced his decision, while denying political motivations.

The move overturns the Biden administration’s 2023 decision to keep the headquarters in Colorado Springs. Colorado officials, including Republican ally Rep. Lauren Boebert, condemned the reversal, arguing it would delay strategic efforts and waste billions. Business leaders in Denver also expressed concern, projecting a $1 billion local economic loss.

U.S. Space Command, distinct from the Space Force, oversees military satellite operations and space defense. As space becomes a key area of international military competition, especially with China's rapid advancements, the headquarters’ location is strategically significant. Huntsville, already a defense and aerospace hub home to NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center and major contractors, offers infrastructure to support growth.

entries.title: Mexico overtakes China as the leading source of goods imported by US
entries.snippet: En 2023, México superó a China como la principal fuente de bienes importados por los Estados Unidos, un cambio que refleja las crecientes tensiones entre Washington y Beijing, así como los esfuerzos de EE.UU. por importar de países más amistosos y cercanos. Según el Departamento de Comercio de EE.UU., el valor de las importaciones de México aumentó casi un 5% a más de $475 mil millones, mientras que el de las importaciones chinas cayó un 20% a $427 mil millones. El deterioro de las relaciones económicas entre EE.UU. y China, incluido el mantenimiento de aranceles por parte de las administraciones Trump y Biden, ha impulsado este cambio. La administración Biden ha fomentado la búsqueda de suministros en países aliados ("friend-shoring") y la vuelta de la producción a EE.UU. ("reshoring"). México ha sido un beneficiario clave, pero también ha sido aprovechado por fabricantes chinos. El cambio también refleja la preocupación por las políticas económicas de China bajo Xi Jinping y su impacto en la economía.

entries.title: Mexico vows retaliation to Trump tariffs without detailing targets
entries.snippet: La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, ordenó el sábado aranceles retaliatorios en respuesta a la decisión de EE.UU. de imponer aranceles del 25% a todos los productos provenientes de México, desencadenando una guerra comercial entre ambos países. Sheinbaum indicó que, a pesar de buscar el diálogo, México se vio obligado a responder con una serie de medidas, aunque no especificó qué productos de EE.UU. serían afectados. Los aranceles estadounidenses violan el Tratado entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá (T-MEC). México ha preparado posibles aranceles de entre 5% y 20% para productos como cerdo, queso, productos frescos, acero y aluminio, aunque la industria automotriz inicialmente será exenta. EE.UU. es el mercado extranjero más importante para México, que envía grandes volúmenes de productos agrícolas y recibe maíz y granos estadounidenses. Se teme que estos aranceles puedan reducir las exportaciones de México y afectar significativamente su PIB. Además, Sheinbaum rechazó las acusaciones de la Casa Blanca sobre una supuesta alianza con cárteles de drogas y defendió las acciones de su gobierno contra el tráfico de fentanilo y la detención de personas vinculadas al narcotráfico.

entries.title: México supera por primera vez a China como principal exportador de EE UU desde 2002
entries.snippet: En 2023, México superó a China por primera vez desde 2002 como el principal exportador a Estados Unidos, con exportaciones que sumaron 475.606 millones de dólares, un aumento del 4,6% respecto a 2022. China, en cambio, exportó un 20% menos, alcanzando 427.229 millones de dólares. La proporción de productos chinos en las importaciones estadounidenses bajó al 13,9%, la cifra más baja desde 2004. Esta reconfiguración se debe a los esfuerzos de EEUU por "desacoplar" su economía de China, iniciados durante el mandato de Donald Trump, y a la promoción de México como destino para empresas que desean relocalizarse del país asiático. Además de México, India, Vietnam, Polonia, Indonesia y Rumania también han llenado el vacío dejado por China. México enfrenta desafíos relacionados con infraestructura, pero la percepción positiva entre las empresas es que el país puede crecer y aprovechar la oportunidad del nearshoring.

entries.title: Global AI rush helps ASML post orders beat, but China outlook dims
entries.snippet:
ASML, the world's largest supplier of chip-making equipment, reported solid third-quarter 2025 results, driven by global AI-related investments. The company posted net bookings of €5.40 billion, slightly above analyst expectations, reflecting strong industry demand for chips required in data centers fueling AI. CEO Christophe Fouquet noted expanding AI-related investments from customers producing both advanced logic and memory chips, with ASML’s technology vital for firms like TSMC, Intel, Samsung, and SK Hynix.

Despite this momentum, ASML forecasted a sharp drop in Chinese demand for 2026. Chinese customers had accounted for nearly a third of tool sales in the first nine months of 2025, making the expected decline notable. Still, overall 2026 sales are projected to remain flat or slightly better, with analysts anticipating potential upgrades in early 2026. Net income for the quarter was €2.12 billion, aligning with market expectations.

entries.title: ASML, Belgium's Imec open laboratory to test newest chip-making tool
entries.snippet: ASML, the world's leading semiconductor equipment manufacturer, has opened a test laboratory in Veldhoven, Netherlands, in collaboration with Belgium's chip research firm Imec. This facility will allow major chipmakers and suppliers to test ASML's cutting-edge High NA EUV lithography tool, valued at 350 million euros. This tool provides up to 60% better resolution than previous models, promising advancements in smaller and faster chip production. ASML expects the tool to be used for commercial manufacturing by 2025-2026. To date, only Intel has received a test machine for its 14A process starting in 2025, and ASML has received over a dozen orders for the new equipment.

entries.title: US-China Trade Tensions Threaten Europe's Biggest Tech Company
entries.snippet: ASML, a Dutch company located in the small town of Veldhoven, has become a crucial player in the global technology industry by building machines that produce semiconductor chips. It is Europe’s largest public tech company by market cap, with a near-monopoly on the advanced extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography systems used to create semiconductor chips. However, ASML's growth is being threatened by US-China trade tensions, which have resulted in the company being blocked from selling its most advanced machines to China. China is a fast-growing market in semiconductor manufacturing, and attempts to restrict its access to global supply chains have led to concerns that China will develop its own alternative to ASML. The US imposes export controls over security concerns, potentially threatening ASML's current revenues and capability to fund further research and development. This geopolitical friction poses a significant challenge to ASML's future dominance in the semiconductor industry.

thoughts.content: We should cover genetic advances (CRISPR, gene therapy) and robotics predictions by GF, possibly citing sources on longevity research or CRISPR approvals, though this isn't essential for an AI focus. We can structure the analysis as “Convergences” and “Contradictions,” referencing the predictions from GF's book. It’ll help us stay organized.

GF predicted U.S. dominance, reinforced by generative AI and tech leadership, like the CHIPS Act and export controls, which limit China’s growth. His view aligns with China’s authoritarian stability but no global dominance. We can source this from his “Next 100 Years” summary, OpenAI Charter, and CHIPS Act. Further dimensions include shifting immigration needs with AI. Non-skilled labor could be reduced by robotics, though immigration remains necessary. Lastly, Japan, Turkey, and Poland rise with AI-enabled defense.

thoughts.summary: Examining Tech Predictions: Space, Robotics, and Mexico’s Role
thoughts.content:
GF predicted space militarization by the 2040s, supported by the creation of the Space Force in 2019, ASAT actions, and AI in satellite management. For robotics, AI and automation enhance productivity, but long-term, AI may affect low-wage advantages, especially in nearshoring Mexico. Lastly, the energy demands of AI could push energy shifts toward renewables and nuclear. 

Contradictions arise with geography versus dematerialization, as AI relies on geographical dependencies like fabs in Taiwan/US/EU despite reductions in physical geography's central role.

GF's prediction on global wars brings a paradox: while he predicted hypersonic and space-based war systems by 2050, advances in AI could also shift warfare to cyber and economic arenas, reducing conflicts like the "Thanksgiving 2050" scenario. Similarly, immigration remains politically stalled, though AI might reduce dependency on labor. Regarding authoritarian resilience, GF revised his forecast from fragmentation to consolidation, seeing AI surveillance as a tool for strengthening authoritarian regimes.

GF's state-driven approach might overlook the growing non-state power of AI labs, impacting his narrative on state dominance. On energy and climate, while AI may increase energy demands, it also opens avenues for energy transitions. Adjusted forecasts for 2028–2045 show a quieter U.S. period, with increasing AI-driven complexities like satellite management and "grey zone" conflicts.

parts:
Here’s a clean way to think about it: take Friedman’s structural frame (geography, demography, state power, long cycles) and lay the AI stack (models→agents→compute→energy→chips→labs) on top. Where they reinforce each other, expect acceleration; where they cut against each other, expect tension—and revisions to his 2028-2045 arc.

# TL;DR (decision-useful)
- **Friedman’s core bets**—U.S. primacy, demographic drag in rich countries, the rise of Japan/Turkey/Poland, and early space militarization—*mostly* survive 2028-2045. In places they’re already materializing (Japan’s rearmament; Poland’s re-armament; Turkey’s drone-driven power projection; militarized space). citeturn3search9turn3search6turn3search7turn3search8turn8search0turn8news36  
- **He underweighted AI** (he explicitly said he couldn’t factor AI well in his U.S. cycles book). The AI stack will *amplify* some of his dynamics (U.S. lead, robotics easing labor shortages) and *undercut* others (cheap-labor advantages; the need for mass immigration at U.S. scale; the timing/character of mid-century conflict). citeturn2view0  
- **Compute, chips, and energy become geopolitics.** U.S.-led export controls + CHIPS policy tie AI leadership to allied industrial bases (US/EU/Japan/Taiwan), aligning with his U.S.-centric forecast and pressuring China—consistent with Stratfor’s own revisions favoring authoritarian consolidation over fragmentation. citeturn7search0turn7search2turn7search1turn1search21  
- **AI’s power footprint is large.** Data-center electricity roughly *doubling* by 2030 (base case) makes energy policy a first-order geopolitical variable in the 2030s; it also dovetails with Friedman’s expectation of a major tech/energy shift. citeturn4search0  
- **Mexico’s rise remains intact** (nearshoring, trade share), but AI+automation narrows the simple “low-wage labor = advantage” story Friedman leaned on; proximity + rule-of-law + grid/ports matter more than wage arbitrage. citeturn9news19turn9search12

---

# 1) Friedman’s baseline for ~2028-2045 (from *The Next 100 Years* and later work)
- **U.S. primacy endures**; China faces internal constraints; Russia wanes; new regional powers emerge (Japan, Turkey, Poland); Mexico rises later in the century. Space becomes a military domain by the 2040s; robotics/genetics reshape productivity and longevity. citeturn0search0  
- **Demographic drag** in developed states drives immigration competition in the 2020s/30s; later, robots reduce labor scarcity. citeturn1search21  
- In **U.S. cycles**, Friedman forecast institutional & socio-economic cycles peaking in the late 2020s, with a new phase beginning in the early 2030s; he also **explicitly notes** AI was a variable he didn’t model. citeturn2view0

**What’s already visible in 2024-2025 that lines up with his thesis?**  
- **Japan**: 2022-27 defense build-up to ~2% of GDP; long-range strike plans; accelerated missile deployments. citeturn3search9turn3search6turn3news34  
- **Poland**: rapid rearmament (HIMARS, K2/K9), personnel expansion—on track for Europe’s strongest land forces. citeturn3news38turn3search1turn3search10  
- **Turkey**: sovereign drone industry and “strategic autonomy” doctrine projecting power regionally. citeturn3search8turn3search11  
- **Space militarization**: US Space Force (2019), ongoing ASAT concerns; space is openly contested. citeturn8search0turn8news36

---

# 2) What the AI wave adds (2028-2045)
Think in “stack” terms:

**a) Models & reasoning/agents.**  
By the early 2030s, enterprise software becomes agent-first (with a hype-cycle cull in the late 2020s). Gartner/Reuters expect many “agentic AI” projects to fail near-term, but a sustained shift toward autonomous task execution by the late 2020s/early 2030s. citeturn6search18turn6search16turn6news21

**b) Compute & chips.**  
U.S.-aligned control points (NVIDIA platforms; EUV monopoly via ASML; advanced-node foundries dominated by TSMC; export controls) make AI capacity a **coalition asset**, reinforcing U.S. primacy in Friedman's frame. citeturn4search1turn11search11turn11news21turn7search0

**c) Energy.**  
IEA base case: data-center power use ≈ *double* by 2030 (≈945 TWh). Energy becomes a limiting reagent for AI scale; expect grid, siting, and generation to be strategic instruments across the 2030s. citeturn4search0

**d) Labor & demography.**  
AI + robotics can substitute for some labor (esp. routine knowledge work) and complement elsewhere; in aging OECD economies, AI dampens but does not erase the demographic tax. Net: immigration pressure softens in some sectors, but care, trades, and defense stay labor-hungry. citeturn5search3turn10search3

---

# 3) Convergences with Friedman (things AI strengthens)

1) **U.S. primacy** through the AI-compute-chip alliance system (CHIPS Act, export controls) → consistent with his long-run U.S. lead. citeturn7search1turn7search0  
2) **Japan/Turkey/Poland rise** gets an AI-defense kicker (C4ISR, missiles, drones), accelerating their regional weight during 2028-2045. citeturn3search9turn3search6turn3search8  
3) **Robotics easing labor scarcity** in aging societies matches his demographic arc; AI makes this far broader than factory floors (agents handling services/admin/R&D). citeturn5search3  
4) **Space militarization**: AI-enabled ISR, autonomous satellites, threat detection—directly in the lane of his 2040s space conflict intuition. citeturn8news36  
5) **Mexico’s momentum** via nearshoring and U.S. trade integration through the 2030s is already visible; AI/automation + proximity keeps it competitive despite rising wages. citeturn9news19

---

# 4) Contradictions / places to revise

1) **Geography vs. software leverage.**  
Friedman’s model is state-first and geography-anchored; AI creates *firm-centric*, globally deployable capabilities. Yet the *physical* stack (fabs, EUV, power) re-anchors advantage in allied territories. Net: revise to “dual sovereignty”—states plus a handful of system-critical firms. citeturn11search11

2) **Immigration in the 2030s.**  
He foresaw intense competition for migrants; AI likely *reduces* the depth/breadth of that competition in white-collar services, though demographics still bite in care, construction, defense. Expect more targeted migration rather than blanket liberalization. citeturn5search3

3) **China’s trajectory.**  
His early bet on fragmentation was walked back by Stratfor in favor of authoritarian re-centralization—*and* AI tools tilt toward regime resilience (surveillance, censorship) over fragmentation. Keep the “internal strain” thesis, drop the “fragmentation as base case.” citeturn1search21

4) **Mid-century war style.**  
A 2050s “space-centric kinetic war” may be displaced by *protracted gray-zone conflict* (space disabling, cyber, economic coercion) long before any set-piece war. AI raises first-strike and miscalculation risks but also strengthens surveillance/deterrence. Down-weight a Thanksgiving-style bolt-from-the-blue. citeturn8news35

5) **Energy assumptions.**  
He anticipated a tech/energy shift (even space solar). The *scale* of AI’s energy appetite makes energy security a hard constraint by the 2030s—policy, not just technology adoption, will drive outcomes. citeturn4search0

---

# 5) Integrated outlook for 2028-2045

**2028-2032:** U.S. cycles settle into a new phase; AI agents diffuse but with high project attrition; compute export controls harden; Japan/Poland solidify rearmament; Turkey continues strategic autonomy; space domain risk rises (ASAT, jamming). citeturn2view0turn6news21turn7search0turn3search9turn3search10turn8news36

**2033-2038:** Energy bottlenecks and grid constraints dominate AI scaling; sovereign AI (national stacks) spread across G20; Mexico entrenches as U.S. partner despite trade frictions. Europe’s defense posture rebalances around Poland; Japan’s strike-back posture matures. citeturn4search0turn9news20turn3search7turn3news34

**2039-2045:** Space becomes the decisive sensor/comm layer for all theaters; conflict remains hybrid/attritional unless a major miscalculation occurs. AI’s productivity lift offsets part of the demographic drag, but not all; immigration is targeted, not wholesale. U.S. primacy persists, now explicitly coupled to AI-chip-energy control points. citeturn8news36turn5search3

---

# Bottom line
Friedman’s *structure over headlines* method still travels well. The AI revolution doesn’t overturn it; it **routes power through new chokepoints** (compute, chips, energy, talent) that—critically—sit inside the very U.S.-aligned geography he highlighted. Where he needs updating is **how** labor, energy, and conflict dynamics play out: less mass immigration and cheap labor as the growth engine; more power-grid and chip-tool diplomacy; fewer “big wars,” more **long shadow conflicts** in space/cyber/economy.

If you want, I can turn this into a table (“Friedman claim → 2025 status → AI impact → 2028-2045 implication”) for quick reference.

---

# Sources / anchors
- Friedman’s books & model: *The Next 100 Years*; *The Storm Before the Calm* (incl. his note that AI wasn’t modeled). citeturn0search3turn0search0turn2view0  
- Stratfor/GPF revisions on China/Russia. citeturn1search21  
- Japan rearmament; Poland’s buildup; Turkey’s drone power. citeturn3search9turn3search6turn3news34turn3search7turn3search1turn3search8  
- Space militarization (USSF; ASAT/nuclear-ASAT reporting). citeturn8search0turn8news36  
- AI energy footprint: IEA projections to 2030. citeturn4search0  
- AI agents/enterprise adoption (and near-term attrition). citeturn6search18turn6search16turn6news21  
- U.S. export controls & CHIPS: BIS/CRS and White House fact sheets. citeturn7search0turn7search2turn7search1  
- Mexico nearshoring / trade share. citeturn9news19  
- Demographic drag (OECD/UN). citeturn5search3turn5search2  
- OpenAI’s AGI definition (for “OpenAI sense”). citeturn4search5

supporting_websites.title: US Space Force warns of 'mind-boggling' build-up of Chinese capabilities
supporting_websites.snippet: General Chance Saltzman, chief of the US Space Force, has expressed significant concerns over China's rapid expansion of military capabilities in space, warning of the increased risk of orbital warfare. He emphasized that the number and speed of development of Chinese space weapons are alarming. During his European tour, Saltzman highlighted the necessity of cooperation between the US and European allies to bolster deterrence capabilities. The US Space Force, established in 2019 by then-president Donald Trump, monitors over 46,000 objects in orbit and has about 10,000 personnel. China and Russia have developed advanced satellite technologies, raising security concerns. Despite Beijing's dismissal of US claims, President Xi Jinping has restructured space, cyber, and information operations within the Chinese military. The US remains reliant on private sector partnerships, including with Elon Musk's SpaceX, to advance its space defenses amidst ongoing global competition.

items.title: Mexico overtakes China as the leading source of goods imported by US
items.snippet: En 2023, México superó a China como la principal fuente de bienes importados por los Estados Unidos, un cambio que refleja las crecientes tensiones entre Washington y Beijing, así como los esfuerzos de EE.UU. por importar de países más amistosos y cercanos. Según el Departamento de Comercio de EE.UU., el valor de las importaciones de México aumentó casi un 5% a más de $475 mil millones, mientras que el de las importaciones chinas cayó un 20% a $427 mil millones. El deterioro de las relaciones económicas entre EE.UU. y China, incluido el mantenimiento de aranceles por parte de las administraciones Trump y Biden, ha impulsado este cambio. La administración Biden ha fomentado la búsqueda de suministros en países aliados ("friend-shoring") y la vuelta de la producción a EE.UU. ("reshoring"). México ha sido un beneficiario clave, pero también ha sido aprovechado por fabricantes chinos. El cambio también refleja la preocupación por las políticas económicas de China bajo Xi Jinping y su impacto en la economía.

supporting_websites.title: Japan accelerates missile deployment amid rising regional tensions
supporting_websites.snippet:
Japan is expediting its deployment of domestically developed long-range missiles amid rising tensions in the region. The Defense Ministry announced plans to roll out the Type-12 anti-ship missiles with a 1,000 km range at Camp Kengun in Kumamoto by March 2026—one year ahead of schedule. This acceleration aligns with Japan’s strategic move to bolster its strike-back capabilities, especially in response to China’s assertive naval actions, North Korea’s threats, and concerns about Russia.

Breaking from its post-WWII pacifist stance, Japan had already shifted defense policies in 2022, adopting a five-year strategy identifying China as a primary threat and strengthening ties with the U.S. As part of this military buildup, Japan aims to increase defense spending to 2% of GDP by 2027. The Defense Ministry has requested a record ¥8.8 trillion ($59.9 billion) budget for fiscal 2026, prioritizing long-range missiles and drones. Alongside the Type-12 missiles, Japan will also deploy U.S.-made Tomahawk missiles and seek to enhance coastal defense with unmanned aerial, surface, and underwater drones to address military understaffing due to its aging population.

items.title: Poland prepares for talks on buying over 100 HIMARS rocket launchers
items.snippet: Poland is gearing up for negotiations to secure over 100 HIMARS rocket launchers from U.S. defense contractor Lockheed Martin, as part of a framework agreement for 486 units. General Artur Kuptel from the Armaments Agency indicated that these talks would commence soon, despite allegations of procurement delays by the current ruling coalition, which assumed power in December 2023. Poland plans significant defense spending, allocating 4.1% of GDP to defense in 2024, the highest among NATO countries, with an increase to 4.7% promised in 2025. Poland has been arranging other defense procurements, including a precision rocket system from South Korea and an order for 72 K239 Chunmoo rocket launchers, with deliveries starting in 2026. Local production of ammunition for these systems is also planned.

supporting_websites.title: Over 40% of agentic AI projects will be scrapped by 2027, Gartner says
supporting_websites.snippet: According to a report by Gartner, over 40% of agentic artificial intelligence (AI) projects are expected to be scrapped by the end of 2027 due to rising costs and unclear business value. Despite significant investments from major tech firms like Salesforce and Oracle in AI systems that can autonomously carry out tasks, many of these projects remain in early, experimental stages and are often driven by hype rather than practical application. Gartner notes a trend of “agent washing,” where vendors mislabel conventional AI tools as agentic without true autonomous capabilities. Currently, only about 130 vendors genuinely offer agentic AI among thousands claiming to do so. Gartner's Anushree Verma highlights that most current agentic AI lacks the maturity to deliver real returns on investment and cannot yet handle complex or nuanced instructions. However, the firm predicts improvements, projecting that by 2028, 15% of day-to-day business decisions will be autonomously made using agentic AI, and 33% of enterprise software applications will incorporate such technology, up significantly from 2024 levels.

supporting_websites.title: ASML Holding
ASML, Belgium's Imec open laboratory to test newest chip-making tool
supporting_websites.snippet: ASML, the world's leading semiconductor equipment manufacturer, has opened a test laboratory in Veldhoven, Netherlands, in collaboration with Belgium's chip research firm Imec. This facility will allow major chipmakers and suppliers to test ASML's cutting-edge High NA EUV lithography tool, valued at 350 million euros. This tool provides up to 60% better resolution than previous models, promising advancements in smaller and faster chip production. ASML expects the tool to be used for commercial manufacturing by 2025-2026. To date, only Intel has received a test machine for its 14A process starting in 2025, and ASML has received over a dozen orders for the new equipment.

items.title: The Next 100 Years: A Forecast for the 21st Century
Hijacked satellites and orbiting space weapons: In the 21st century, space is the new battlefield
items.snippet:
In the 21st century, space has emerged as a critical battlefield alongside land, sea, air, and cyberspace. The article, dated August 18, 2025, details the growing threat posed by space-based cyber and physical attacks. For example, pro-Russian hackers hijacked a satellite broadcasting in Ukraine, replacing programming with Russian military parade footage. Such actions demonstrate how easily satellites, which support GPS, military operations, and communications, can be compromised.

Over 12,000 satellites orbit Earth, making them vulnerable to cyber intrusions, particularly via outdated software. The 2022 hack on the Viasat network during the Russian invasion of Ukraine exemplifies this risk. U.S. officials also warn of a developing Russian nuclear anti-satellite weapon intended to cripple all satellites in low-Earth orbit, evoking Cold War-era fears akin to a new “Cuban Missile Crisis.”

Additionally, competition for lunar resources, particularly by the U.S., Russia, and China, is heating up. Nations plan nuclear-powered lunar bases to exploit materials like helium-3 for future energy production. The U.S. is advancing its security efforts through the Space Force and unmanned missions like the X-37B.

Tensions and strategic investments reflect a new era where control of space could determine future geopolitical and economic dominance.

supporting_websites.title: Mexico vows retaliation to Trump tariffs without detailing targets
supporting_websites.snippet: La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, ordenó el sábado aranceles retaliatorios en respuesta a la decisión de EE.UU. de imponer aranceles del 25% a todos los productos provenientes de México, desencadenando una guerra comercial entre ambos países. Sheinbaum indicó que, a pesar de buscar el diálogo, México se vio obligado a responder con una serie de medidas, aunque no especificó qué productos de EE.UU. serían afectados. Los aranceles estadounidenses violan el Tratado entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá (T-MEC). México ha preparado posibles aranceles de entre 5% y 20% para productos como cerdo, queso, productos frescos, acero y aluminio, aunque la industria automotriz inicialmente será exenta. EE.UU. es el mercado extranjero más importante para México, que envía grandes volúmenes de productos agrícolas y recibe maíz y granos estadounidenses. Se teme que estos aranceles puedan reducir las exportaciones de México y afectar significativamente su PIB. Además, Sheinbaum rechazó las acusaciones de la Casa Blanca sobre una supuesta alianza con cárteles de drogas y defendió las acciones de su gobierno contra el tráfico de fentanilo y la detención de personas vinculadas al narcotráfico.

items.title: Mexico overtakes China as the leading source of goods imported by US
items.snippet: En 2023, México superó a China como la principal fuente de bienes importados por los Estados Unidos, un cambio que refleja las crecientes tensiones entre Washington y Beijing, así como los esfuerzos de EE.UU. por importar de países más amistosos y cercanos. Según el Departamento de Comercio de EE.UU., el valor de las importaciones de México aumentó casi un 5% a más de $475 mil millones, mientras que el de las importaciones chinas cayó un 20% a $427 mil millones. El deterioro de las relaciones económicas entre EE.UU. y China, incluido el mantenimiento de aranceles por parte de las administraciones Trump y Biden, ha impulsado este cambio. La administración Biden ha fomentado la búsqueda de suministros en países aliados ("friend-shoring") y la vuelta de la producción a EE.UU. ("reshoring"). México ha sido un beneficiario clave, pero también ha sido aprovechado por fabricantes chinos. El cambio también refleja la preocupación por las políticas económicas de China bajo Xi Jinping y su impacto en la economía.
